It started with a warm greeting from the same gentleman Arthur, we were seated in a very spacious booth and greeted by our server who was attentive, knowledgeable and very friendly. She took our drinks order, and returned with it very quickly. Shortly after, Arthur returned with the very creative Chef, Dejan Djuckic who presented us with a tasty and perfectly presented appetizer. 
We placed our order, and embarked on a journey. We experienced something new, a truly fine meal. We began with the salad and avocado toast, the ingredients were perfectly balanced which awakened our palate. The main course, was made with fresh and top notch ingredients. Our Prime NY steak was a fine piece of meat raised in a reputable ranch. It was cooked perfectly, and paired with their delicious mashed potatoes and savory vegetables. Our second entrée was the Chilean sea bass, a treat. It was cooked perfectly, and paired with the most flavorful Brussel sprouts. Upon completing our meal, we were served the most delightful, visually stimulating and tasty dessert- a dark chocolate brownie was baked perfectly and the components were balanced and complemented each other. 

People are often unkind to members of the service industry, our experience this evening has surpassed any expectations we had. The meal, service, and experience have left us wanting more. My wife and I have traveled extensively and dined in many restaurants and in my opinion the skillful chef at Meritage is one of the finest cooks in Phoenix. We will be returning very soon, hungry for more. Thank you for your efforts to provide us this amazing culinary experience.
A nice gastropub type restaurant. Food and service was great, as were the drinks. All-around nice experience.

1 star for their hand-crafted cocktail experience.  2.5 for the food.  Food was fine--not great, not special, but fine.

When you say "Hand-Crafted" cocktails, it means something.  It includes a quality spirit, maybe a splash of bitters, a little simple syrup, maybe a little citrus, maybe shaken, maybe stirred and likely garnished.  This place claims to be hand crafted, but it is not.  We frequently stay at this resort (quarterly) and was excited to try it out.

I ordered an old fashioned and it was an old fashioned old fashioned, meaning the bartender had to go to the back room to get 2 sugar packets, when the simple syrup was 1 foot away.  There was maraschino cherry and orange muddling, with loose ice chips.  1.5 OZ of Buffalo Trace for $20.  Ridiculous, especially when I was enjoying Tito's cocktails, pool-side for half the price.

My wife ordered a drink from their "Chili's Style" cardboard drink menu.  The bartender had no idea what it was, had to take the drink menu and open it to the right page to make the drink that came out nothing as advertised.  I'm OK paying $20 for a quality cocktail, but this was not.

We found out later that we were there during happy hour.  We ordered our drinks 15 minutes before the end, but was still charged full price.  "Specialty Cocktails" were half price.  

Over charged and underwhelmed.  May try the food again, will not come for the drinks.

Conveniently located within the JW Marriott Desert Ridge Resort.  So hopeful when I walked into the joint, because it was quite pleasing to the eyes, but not so much for the taste buds... sad face.

Food: My friend and I did go around drunch (between lunch and dinner) time, so we experienced their happy hour menu.  Not a bad selection for happy hour.  Let's start with my favorite dish, the Season's Harvest Pickled Vegetables.  My friend's choice, did not sound so appetizing, but boy was I wrong.  The veggies were pickled to perfection.  You can tell that each veggie was pickled in a different brine, because you get a different experience, whether it be sweet, tart, spicy, or smokey with each crunchy bite.  Did I mention crunchy, how are these veggies so so so so crunchy after that pickling.  Overall amazing.  

Next we had the corn frites, would def not recommend this dish.  It was extremely salty... extremely salty.  Fried to perfection, but don't think it is something that I would get again.  

Moving on to the fish and chips.  The fish was very light, flaky, and moist.  I think the batter could have used a bit of seasoning, slightly on the bland side.  It came with a caper remoulade, which could have used a bit more flavor as well.  It was just missing a pinch of something.

Grand finale was the apple crisp.  Nice and crispy caramelized filo.  Had a nice cinnamon-sugar flavor.  We broke it apart and ate it with the tart apples.  Would have been nice if the apples were cooked down a little more, so they could be nice and soft.  Slightly too tart for me.  So if you have a sweet tooth post meal, this may not be the dessert for you.

Service: I'm pretty sure at any other time of day there is a hostess, but not during drunch.  We walked in and was greeted by .... nothing.  Now we stood in a bit of confusion.  So then after a good minute of looking and being awkward, I asked the bartender if we should seat ourselves.  Answer was yes.  After that, it was smooth sailing.  Our waitress was prompt with keeping drinks full, clearing away dishes, providing information about the menu, and had such a welcoming smile.
  
Ambiance: casual, urban/rustic.  The interior of this place had a restoration hardware kind of feel, which I absolutely love.  Very laid back, get your day drink on kind of atmosphere.

Dranks: Had some decent beer selections on draft, including some local beers.  Make sure to ask if they have the beer you want prior to getting all excited.  Just because it is on the list, does not mean they will always have it available.  Pretty good wine by glass option.  If all else fails, full bar baby.

Overall: Loved the atmosphere.  A place where you can just kick back, grab a couple of drinks, and relax.  Not a huge palate pleaser when it comes to their dishes, but def a good place to grab a few drinks, and chat it up with friends.  Enjoy!!
Great option on campus at the JW.  Food was great and atmosphere very cool. Try the strip steak. Probably more adult than kid friendly.

Service feels a bit slow. The waitresses are good, but I suspect the kitchen is understaffed. I'm not sure; either way, the restaurant is not even half full. 

In their defense, we did have a party of 15+.

Spinach and artichoke dip was not quite what I expected. I did not enjoy the flavor at all. The guyere cheese is so strong that it destroys the flavor of everything else in the dip and just tastes like a cheese sauce. This might be the most unhealthy tasting spinach dip I've ever had in my life. The flatbread went fine with it, but the mushy oven crackers did not. 

Appetizer with the mussels was okay. They didn't really do anything with it. 

Bread rolls were generic ones that you could buy from any grocery store and were not soft or warm, the way I like them. For some reason, they served them after most people were done with their entrees, which makes zero sense. Did they forget to bring them out earlier? 

Most of the portions are pretty small. For the most part, the level of quality doesn't justify the cost. This place is fake classy/fancy: dress up your mediocre food with expensive decorations, European-ish names, a wine list, and more effort in plating. 

Case in point, my scallops entree was just 4 big scallops with condiments. Granted, that's not super unusual, but they did virtually nothing to enhance its umami and almost every bite had sand in it. If I didn't know better, I might guess that sand was the main ingredient in their recipe.
